lg.l: A man with expence and Infinite Toyll,
By planting and Dunging enobled his Soyle,
There fruits of ye best ye tast did invite
And uniform order still courted the sight
No degenerate weed this rich ground did produce
But all things produc'd both beauty and use
T'ill from Dunghill transplanted while yet but a Seed
A Nettle rear'd up his inglorious head
The Gardiner wou'd wisely rooted him up
To stop ye increase of a Barbarous cropp
But ye master forbad him──and after ye fashion
Of foolish good name and mild Moderation
Forbore him through pity, and chose as much rather
To ask him some questions first; how he came thither
Kind Sr quoth ye Nettle a Stranger I come
Cause I would not subscribe to a mistery dark
That the Prince of all Trees was ye Iesuits Bark
An Erroneous Tenet; I know Sr that you
No more then myself will allow to be true
To you I for refuge & Sanctuary sue
There's none so renowned for Compassion as you
And thô in somethings I may differ from these
The rest of you Faithfull & beautifull Trees
Though yor Digging my Nature much harms
And I Can not Comply wth your Gardiner in Formes
Yet I and my family after one fashion
Will peacably stick to our own Education
Be pleas'd to allow us a place for to rest in
For ye rest of your trees we'll never molest e'm
A kind shelter to us and protection afford
we'l do you no harme Sr Il'e give you my word
The good man was soon won wth this plausible Tale
So fraud and good nature do'es often prevaile
He welcomes his Guest gives him free Toleration
In the midst of his Garden to take up his Station,
And into his bosom do'es his Enemy bring
He never Suspected the Nettle coul'd Sting
Till flush'd with Success, of Strength to be fear'd
Around him a numerous offspring he rear'd
Then ye master grew sensible what he had done,
and faine wou'd have had his new Guest to be gone
But now t'was to late to bid him turn out.
A well rooted possession already was got.
The old Trees decay'd & in their room Grew
A stubborn wrank pestilent poisonous crew.
The master who first ye young brood had admitted
They stung like Ingrates & left him unpitty'd
No help from Manuring or Planting was found
The weeds had eat out the heart of ye Grownd
Thus one Nettle Uncrop't increas'd to Such Store
That was nothing but weeds what was Garden beforeX85-210L
